history.content: EE 120 is not required at all for 106A. It used to be required a while back, but requirements have not updated. 120 is a great class though, and may make it easier to do cool things in your final project. Source: 106A TA last sem, 106B TA now

children.subject: I think we like to say that our prereqs are freshman linear alg (Math 54 level) and python (61A level), and then anything beyond that can only help you but isn't required. Phrasing it this way since we get a fair number of students outside of EECS who do not touch the 16 series. +1 to some mechanics background being useful
Can you elaborate on "anything beyond that can only help"? What classes would help?

The math in the class is pretty linear algebra heavy, so having taken anything beyond a first course in linear algebra (ie. 54 would be a first course, 16 series together is more than 54 but I would not count 16A doing enough, something like Math 110 would be a second course) would help you with understanding lecture content and hw. We start to do more mechanics related things in the latter part of the class which you only need high school level physics knowledge to be comfortable with, but of course if you have taken higher level courses (Phys 7A or anything else I don't really know much of that department) that would help. Some knowledge of classical control is helpful for mid to latter parts of the class, which EE 120/ME 132 provides and EE 128/ME 134 gives even more of, but 16B does more than enough. However, if you have advanced controls knowledge (from the upper div classes I listed + grad courses like EE 221A, 222, etc.) it becomes easier to do really fun stuff in your final project. The class also has a sizable vision component, so having seen similar material in CS 194-26, CS 184 could be useful for digesting that material better and also being better equipped to do more advanced vision work in your final project.184 also covers some rigid body motion which a lot of time is spent on in this class. 188 content could also help you do more advanced path planning things in your final project. I would like to say every upper div EE/CS class gives you some additional knowledge that you can find a way to use in your final project lol, but this is just the specific stuff I could think of.

I think just 16B is enough linear algebra for the class. Math 110 goes into way more proofs than you'll ever need. Other than linear algebra, 106A is very self contained. It uses bits of all different areas of math/CS/physics like Jay mentioned and teaches it to you with no background needed.

Also personally, I think 120/128 are not very helpful for 106A/B. If you're interested in controls, I recommend instead taking 221A/222.
Thank you for the clarification Mr. Vangipuram

I would recommend 287 if you're interested in probabilistic robotics and control algorithms. The 106 series is not geared towards academic research or theoretical work.

106AB is a hand-on laboratory course, and IMO the fact that it's X-listed with BioE tells you how rigorous it's going to be. Other good classes in the area to take (as mentioned before) are EE 120, 128, 221A for classical control theory and the ML sequence (126, 127, 189, 182). Even though recent robotics research has pivoted away from classical controls, it's definitely still very useful to have under your belt as a lot of the ideas for modern methods come from classical theory (ie filter banks help you understand CNNs).

@Ashwin There are differences between what is presented in 128 and 221A. 221A is a class in state space, 128 is a class in frequency methods. As a controls engineer, you need to know both very well; 221A is not a substitute for 128. State-space is definitely the hotter area right now, but not knowing the style of control taught in 128 will be a significant handicap in the long run.

Also, 120 is a prereq for 221A. It's probably doable without 120, but 120 dives directly into frequency-domain control of MIMO systems and if you've never seen SISO frequency domain before, you're gonna have quite a bit of self-study to do. 221A is not the class to get your first exposure to the Laplace transform.
*221A dives directly into frequency-domain control of MIMO systems
Yea this is true. I thought 221A was doable without 120 but I would've liked to see the Laplace transform before

@beaker, 106A is a relatively friendly intro to robotics and the math behind it with lots of hands-on lab portions. While it's gotten more rigorous since prof Sastry took over 2 years ago, it's still around average for an upper-div eecs class. It's not very research oriented.

106B on the other hand is very high-level and very research-oriented, especially since prof Sastry took over. You read a lot of papers, implement several in the projects, and write a research paper as your final project. The topics in the class are absolutely relevant in modern robotics research, but don't have too much overlap with the material in 287 (prof Abbeel teaches things that are useful in his research, while prof Sastry teaches things that are useful in his).

@Beaker, Friendly reminder that a lot of BioEs are interested in assistive devices like prosthetics and assistive robotics, like that which is the focus of the HART Lab! Being cross-listed with BioE really means nothing other than that it may also be of interest to BioEs; it says nothing about rigor. We do our best to support students from all different backgrounds, which probably is what lends Ashwin to say it's "self-contained." Anyone who's interested in robotics should be supported to try their hand at it. 

Source: your friendly neighborhood C106AB Head TA (who is also incidentally a BioE grad)

What Beaker said is true, except for "106AB is a hand-on laboratory course, and IMO the fact that it's X-listed with BioE tells you how rigorous it's going to be." This is probably why all the 106 people are here. EE 221A and EE 128 are different. Take 221/222 only if you want to go to grad school.

What I meant is that there's a difference in assumable mathematical background between BioE and EECS.

It's not realistic to assume that BioE majors take 126, 127, and 189 since that would also require them to take a whopping 6 out-of-major classes since they would need to take the 16 trilogy to get started. As a result of the need to cater to people who aren't EECS, the class naturally needs to be designed in a way that's self-contained and accessible. IMO this limits the depth of stuff that can be covered, so you're not going to be able to get into the weeds of say optimizer design or image segmentation, the areas where a lot of foundational robotics research happens.

I guess when I said research, I was specifically referring to a style of robotics grounded in computer vision and reinforcement learning. So maybe the correct terminology would be foundational research as opposed to applications-based research. For the purposes of the former, lab time isn't important as being super solid at optimization, probability, and programming.

... it's funny you dismiss model-based robotics research as "applications-based", when dynamics, path planning, and model predictive control literally serve as the "foundation" of many modern RL-based methods. Meanwhile, a lot of the robotics research that goes on in BWW might be described as "applications-based". I understand what you're trying to say, but it comes off as needlessly inflammatory. To me, the distinction feels a bit arbitrary; applications motivate theory which itself motivates new applications. Theorists often work with experimentalists, and many researchers do both. A lot of my colleagues in Cory collaborate closely with researchers in Etch and BWW; it's all connected.

You're also assuming that a field is rigorous if and only if it uses probability and optimization (EECS 126 and 127). There's a lot of pretty legit math that isn't really covered in the core EECS curriculum. For example, 106B (and 106A to a lesser degree) depend heavily on geometry and analysis, which aren't as useful on the discrete spaces most CS classes deal with. Since these subjects are also frequently used in mechanics and control, many bioengineers, mechanical engineers, and physics majors are better prepared for the math in 106A than EECS and CS majors.

There's also a lot more to computer vision than image segmentation, and the 106 series covers the more geometric methods quite deeply, especially since professor Ma started co-lecturing. I encourage you to check out the 106B course material (https://ucb-ee106.github.io/106b-sp21site/)! Hopefully it'll provide a complementary perspective to the material in 287. If you're interested in perception, you might also be interested in the seminar profs Ma and Sastry also teach (https://pages.github.berkeley.edu/ee290-005/sp21-site/), though as a seminar its curriculum isn't particularly structured.

I wasn't trying to dismiss model-based robotics or computer vision. I was giving advice to people who are planning on taking EE 221+222 and CS 280 down the road anyways. It seems like I might have been misinformed on who 106 is geared for (since very few of the people I've talked to in this area of research have suggested taking it). The commonly given advice for UDs from BWW grad students has always been something along the lines of 189/182/127/188/126/120 in roughly decreasing order of utility. Essential grad classes are usually 285/287.

A question for the course staff that have joined this thread: Assuming you have the above background and plan to take dedicated classes in control and vision in PhD (221A, 222, 280), would you still recommend 106? There are probably at least a couple of other people here in my shoes.

If you're planning on doing lots of nonlinear control, 106B is definitely a class you'd want to take. There is a decent amount of overlap between 222 and 106B, since 106B covers the application of many nonlinear controls topics to robotics, but they're different enough that the overlap helps rather than hurts imo. 

The course is pretty new, and has evolved a lot in the past couple years, so I'm not surprised that most of the grad students you've talked to don't know much about it. Esp since it deals with a different type of robotics research than most of the BWW people do. It's pretty high-workload, and it's broad enough that it's probably not useful after the first year of grad school. Most of the students are juniors or seniors intending to go to grad school (MS or PhD) in model-based robotics, with some first-year grad students in the mix.
thanks for all of your replies. Can someone help summarize: What will be the order to take EE 120, EECS 106A, EE 221A, EE 222, or/and any other related classes?
Yea 16B is the only prerequisite. Having knowledge of mechanics/Physics 7A will also help later on in the class.
Cap.
I don't think so but disagree feel free

From everyone I've spoken to in industry, the general consensus is that open ended style projects like those given in 106A/B are the most helpful towards industry. There's no autograder, little to no guidance, no piazza, an infinite number of things that could go wrong, and a necessity for great team dynamics. These are the same reasons that we generally put research, internship, and job experience over class projects and assignments on our resumes.

What you are saying is just project classes in general, and there are plenty of people out there doing their own robotics projects without taking either of 106A/B.

I don't think you really get what I was trying to say.

Sure lets disect your statements one by one.

”The class is just maths and implementation”. Yes, it is. I’m not sure what class you’ve taken but thats pretty much every EE design class. Most EE classes are design by nature unlike CS where you can get away with a lot of theory if youre good at Maths.

”Material and labs are not helpful for project”. Well yes and no. Since the project is open-ended, you are allowed to explore things that the class may or may not have taught you. The labs and material are there for you to get started in thinking what you COULD possibly do with the knowledge taught. So it really is dependant on what you ended up doing that skews your perception on this.

”Lots of people walked into the classes with their project”. Yes some do. Why do you care? Whatever you put into the class is what you get out of it, and that holds true for all classes. People who come with projects done already are wasting an opportunity themselves to explore and do something new.

”Rather useless for industry”. Yes and no, depends on what you want to do. 106A is a gentle introduction into the field of robotics and its possibilities. Its not a one-stop shop where youve mastered the entire robotics field in just 1 class. I can argue CS70, CS170, and CS189 is useless for industry for me as an EE person where as a CS person would probably disagree with me. 

“You can learn materials on your own and start a robotics project without taking the class”. Yes you could. This holds for any class. Not sure what youre argument is here. Like I said, 106A is not a “mastering robotics in 1 class” class. Its meant to show you what robotics entails and what you could do with it, which is why the difficulty and workload is low-medium. 106B goes into much much more detail and specific implementation and is a much harder class
I am not quite sure what/why we are arguing here, but I agree with most of the stuff you wrote.
Leave Anonymous Helix alone

The class is just math and implementations. The materials and labs are not really helpful for the final project.

Lots of people walked into the classes with their projects.

Rather useless for real industry imo.

You could probably learn the materials on your own, and start your own robotics project without taking the class.


Take it if you have nothing else to take and they tend to give good grades. 
Knowing friends in the class also helps you do well and get a good grade in the class.

history.content:
On the website, it list EE 120. I will be a senior next year, and I have not yet taken EE 120. I wonder if I can take EECS 106A? Is EE 120 a hard prereq?

I have taken EE16A/B, EECS 126/127, CS 170/188/189, all the core math major courses and core statistics courses.
history.subject: prereq for EECS 106A?
